title: The High Price of Parking
author: John Dorney
filename: 227 - The High Price of Parking - John Dorney_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
OPENING THEME
1. INT. SPACESHIP
DOOR OPENS. TWO MARRIED ALIENS CLAMBER IN
And you paid for parking, didn’t you?
Yes. Course I did.
Only they don’t let you out the forcewall if you haven’t paid.
I know that. That’s why I did it. (OPERATES THE CONTROLS)
(HEADS INTO THE BACK. SITS) Got some lovely hypercards to post Auntie Jack.
Really.
THE SELFDRIVE FIRES UP
Welcome back, ma’am.
How do Tomas.
Did you have a pleasant visit?
Pretty good, yes.
I’m glad to hear it.
WIFE INPUTTING COMMANDS
Auntie Varn’ll be so jealous. (BEAT) What you doing up there?
Setting the self-drive. How else you reckon we’re getting back?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 3
Oh. Course.
Which destination do you require?
Home please.
And would you prefer the fastest or shortest route?
Fastest. Though if there’s services about halfway, program in a rest stop.
I’ll see if there is. Calculating route. (WHIRR) Yes. The most convenient spaceport is Vildar.
Oh, great. That’s a lovely one. Do that.
I shall. (WHIRRS)
THE ENGINES REV. SHE JOINS HER HUSBAND. HE’S USING A REMOTE
Ready to launch. What you up to?
Looking for an in-flight movie. You like Narl Garfoot, don’t
you?
Narl Garfoot? No. I hate him.
Really? I thought —
Free Parking.
SILENCE
What was that?
Free parking.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 4
You said you'd paid.
I did. (HEADS BACK UP TO THE CONTROL DESK) Must be a bug...
Free Parking. Free Parking.
HE JOINS HER. THE ENGINES GET LOUDER
Something’s wrong with the Self-drive...
Ah, not going to have to get it reinstalled, am I?
Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
Do those engines sound loud to you?
Yeah, they -
THE CONTROLS SPARK AND BURN
What in - ?
Free parking!
THE SHIP EXPLODES
HUSBAND/WIFE:
SCREAMS
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 5
2. INT. PARKING BAY
(MINOR BUSTLE — PASSERS-BY RETURNING TO SPACESHIPS. SOME TAKING
NEARBY AND DEPARTING, BUT IT’S REASONABLY EMPTY. FAINT,
SIREN. THE TARDIS MATERIALISES. ACE EMERGES)
Doctor! I thought you said we were going to the most beautiful planet in the cosmos?
(CALLING FROM INSIDE) One of the most beautiful planets, Ace. I said one of them. I wouldn’t want the others to take offence.
MEL EMERGES
She’s right though, Doctor. Beautiful isn’t the word I’d have picked. Looks more like a municipal car park.
THE DOCTOR EMERGES
Of course it does, Mel. That’s what it is. Well, not a car park, obviously, there are no cars. A spaceship park. For Spaceships. That’s where we are.
Funny definition of beautiful you’ve got.
Oh, this isn’t where we’re going.
(LOCKS THE TARDIS AND WALKS TO A CONTROL TERMINAL. ENTERS
Eh?
I beg your pardon?
We’re going to Dashrah. One time home of the legendary Dream Spinners. Quite an enigmatic race. Vanished in mysterious circumstances many centuries ago.
Oh, here we go. Someone’s playing Sherlock Holmes again.
Well. You know how much I hate not having the answers.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 6
And you’ve never thought to just travel back to whenever it happened to see whatever it was?

Of course not. If there’s something I hate more than not having the answers, it’s cheating. There’s no point in doing a crossword if you’ve always got your thumb in the back of the book, looking at the solution.
If you wanted to do a crossword, I’d expect you to have gone back in time, nobbled the setter and written it yourself.
THE DOCTOR FINISHES WITH THE CONSOLE
Done. All registration details entered.
The TARDIS has registration details?
You'd be surprised. Mind your feet.
My — ? Woah!
(A WHIRR AND ACE HOPS BACK. A LOCKING CLAMP EMERGES FROM THE GROUND AND ATTACHES TO THE TARDIS)
What’s it doing to her?
Magnetic clamps.
Concealed in the floors... Clever.
To keep vehicles in place and prevent theft. (TAPS THE TARDIS) All safely stowed.
A PLASTIC TOKEN CLATTERS FROM THE TERMINAL
There we are. (TAKING IT)
What’s that?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 7
The little token. You can’t park anywhere without a little token.
No sneaking off without paying then?
Even Time Lord technology wouldn’t get past the force barrier here without a receipt. Come along. The travelator to the teleport is over there.
HE HEADS OFF
Better make a note of the bay. You know what he’s like.
Do I ever...
(MUTTERS) Continent T, Violet Zone, Bay... Number... Yeah, got it.
(THEY FOLLOW. AS GO, THE DISTANT SIREN IS CLOSER AND A SHADE
AUDIBLE)
Can you hear that?
(BEAT) Sounds like a car alarm.. Someone’s trying to nick a spaceship. Really is like a municipal car park, isn’t it?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 8
3. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
(ALERT RINGING — SAME AS PREVIOUS SCENE. THE MIDDLE-AGED
WARDENS ARE DOING THEIR BEST TO PANIC. KEMPTON OPERATES
RAPIDLY. COWLEY PACES)
Explosion detected in sector three, ma’am. I’ve locked down the area.
What was it this time, Kempton?
Same as usual. Ship preparing for launch.
How many customers?
Two, I think.
Right. I see. Is it... ‘them’?
No-one’s claimed responsibility yet, ma’am, but it does appear to match their M.O.
Of course it does. Many witnesses?
Well, no. It wasn’t peak time. So the area was relatively under-populated.
Thank heavens we’re down on visitors then. If anyone asks, it was a fault in their ship, alright?
We’ve got the cover story ready to go, ma’am. I’m not sure many people will believe it though. There’ve been an awful lot of ‘faulty ships’ lately.
Yeeeessss.
Are you going to inform head office?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 9
Well, I’ve got to, haven’t I? It’s the job. I don’t have much choice.
I don’t think they’1l be happy.
They so rarely are. Do your best, Kempton. Minimise the disruption as much as possible and we’1ll speak soon, no doubt.
No doubt, Ma’am. All the best.
(COWLEY HEADS OFF. A COMMUNICATION DEVICE BEEPS, AND KEMPTON
Hello, Deputy Warden.
SERAPHIM IS A COMPUTER, BUT SHOULDN’T OBVIOUSLY BE SO
(COMMUNICATOR DISTORT) Good day, Mr Kempton. I’m sorry to disturb you at what must be rather a busy time.
Oh, that’s quite alright, Seraphim. We both know why that is, don’t we?
(DISTORT) Indeed we do. A situation has developed. It requires your urgent attention.
A different situation?
(DISTORT) A being of great interest has landed on Parking. Northern Hemisphere. Continent T, Violet Zone, Bay Omicron, Number Eight hundred and three. This being has much potential.
Really? Then I’11 see if I can procure them for you.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 10
4. INT. CONCOURSE
(THE TARDIS CREW ON A TRAVELATOR. A MORE BUSTLY PART OF PARKING. CROWDS MILLING AROUND)
I presume this place is where we park in order to visit Dashrah.
Quite so. Dashrah’s a planet of exceptional beauty. Historical ruins; multi-coloured, swirling pastel skies; remarkable sunsets...
Sounds pretty boring to me.
Oh, I prefer boring to ‘life-threatening’ any day.

And as you might expect, said beauty has to be protected. Being a major tourist attraction, Dashrah has a lot of visitors, but also a very delicate ecosystem that requires preservation. So the entire planet is looked after by Galactic Heritage.
Oh. Is it.
You know them?
Sort of. Glitz had a run-in with their fleet. They’re like a militarised, space-faring, National Trust.
Right. (THINKING) So like when you visit a historical site on Earth, you aren’t allowed to park your car right on top of it, when you visit Dashrah —
. You park your spaceship on the special planetoid they built next door. Hence the name: ‘Parking’.
An artificial planet?!
And a rather large one, due to Dashrah’s popularity.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 11
‘Parking’? That’s its actual name?
I bet that took a committee months to come up with.
Three and a half years, I believe. But to be fair, they were spending most of that time building it too, so there wasn’t any rush. That was a few thousand years ago.
Explains the décor.
SPACESHIP LAUNCHES IN DISTANCE
Seems very busy.
Actually, I think it might be quieter than usual. We may have arrived in the off-season.
It’s certainly got all the mod-cons. Restaurants, shops... I presume that’s a refuelling station...
Wherever there are people there are opportunities for profit.
You said we were heading for a teleport? Is that like the Park and Ride to Dashrah?
Exactly. Just up here.
HE LEAVES THE TRAVELATOR. ACE AND MEL FOLLOW
So you’re trying to find out what made these Dashrans disappear?
Correct.
Well if it’s likely to involve awakening an ancient evil from the dawn of time, I might just stay here and have a coffee.
SHE STOPS WALKING
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 12
I mean, that place looks nice.
You’re no fun anymore.
I’m sure it won’t come to that. It’s just curiosity. Whatever happened, happened long ago. We’1l1 have no trouble.
(KEMPTON STEPS OUT IN FRONT OF THEM WITH HALF A DOZEN
- SQUAT, WHIRRING BOXES. ALL OF THEM LOAD THEIR
Do not move!
You were saying?
Stop right where you are. You three are under arrest.
Of course we are.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 13
5. INT. DUCTING (TRIBAL LAIR
(TWENTY PEOPLE, VARIOUS RACES, GATHERED AROUND A FLICKERING FIRE IN A FUTURISTIC UNDERCITY/SLUM. A BIT TRIBAL. REGINA TEARS OPEN A BOX)
Ah. Good. A whole delivery of Varl-hen meat.
NOISES OF APPROVAL
It was just lying about, Mother. Left outside the shop to be taken for refuse.
Excellent foraging, Gord. We shall eat well tonight...
TRIBESMAN RUNS UP
(CALLING) Mother Regina! Mother Regina!
Quiet! You wish the Wardens to hear?
I.. No. I do not. Apologies.
What is it?
I — It has happened again, mother.
BEAT
The Free Parkers?
That is the impression I got from the Wardens. I did not hear all they said. They spotted me, but I escaped.
The Free Parkers. Damn them. They shall be the end of us. (BEAT) Gord — hack into the Lodge systems. These rebels must be controlled.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 14
6. INT. TELEPORT STATION
‘Parking outside a marked bay’?
You’re denying it then, sir?
Well, yes.
Of course we’re denying it! Do we look like the sort of people who don’t know how to park properly?
In my experience, Miss, they look just like everyone else.
‘Miss’?
Our ship was clamped into place. It can’t have been outside a marked bay, surely?
She makes an good point, Warden - ?
Deputy Head Warden Kempton. And her good point doesn’t tally with our records, sir. So, if you don’t mind, you’re accompanying me to the Wardens’ Lodge.
And if we do mind?
Then the Robowardens will stun you and drag you there anyway.
Make my day.
THE ROBOWARDENS BRISTLE WITH ENERGY
They make a good point too.
That thing? Looks like a stunted Dalek.
Appearances can be deceptive. I mean, look at the Doctor.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 15
But I have a mystery to solve! The disappearance of the Dream- Spinners won’t untangle itself.
They’ve been gone an awfully long time, sir, I’m sure it’1ll wait thirty minutes.
We'd only be delayed thirty minutes?
That’s not the point.

If you’re innocent, like you say, it’ll be a glitch in the system. We’ll have a quick chat at the Lodge, then get you back here. You’ll be on Dashrah before you know it. I mean, if you are certain you’re innocent.
Doctor. For a quiet life.
BEAT
Oh, very well. Which way to this Lodge, Warden Kempton?
QUICK JUMP CUT TO:
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 16
7. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CELL
BARRED DOOR SLAMS
I don’t know about you, but I reckon this is a cell.
(OUTSIDE) Well, we have to put you somewhere. We’re not presupposing guilt.
But you’re still locking us in.
It’s a security measure.
Deputy Kempton — I thought you implied we weren’t going to be here very long?
And you won’t be. If you’re innocent. But that’s yet to be proven. We can’t have you wandering around when you've potentially committed a very serious crime, now can we?
A parking violation!
On a planet dedicated to parking, Miss, that’s one of the most serious crimes there is.
(MUTTERING) Reckon I could show you a few others.
Can you tell me your reason for arrival?
Tourism.
A likely story. Empty your pockets into the slot.
Ah, you don’t quite understand what you’re asking there. They’re very capacious.
Then perhaps the whole jacket, sir.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 17
That seems a trifle extreme.
Maybe. But if you could.
Why?
Why what?
Why should we hand anything over? You’re not even sure we’ve committed a crime.
Every criminal surrenders their possessions, it’s the rules.
I’m afraid I’m not much of a stickler for rules. Neither, as my friend Mel has so correctly observed, am I currently a criminal.
(MUTTERED) Not on this planet, at any rate.
I am, however, very good at noticing when people are behaving oddly. And you are behaving very oddly indeed.
(FAKE LAUGH) I don’t think I am.

There seem to be several wardens patrolling this planet. Those things you call Robowardens too. Any one of them could have arrested us. And yet we were honoured with the attention of the Deputy Head Warden. I wonder why?
As I said, it’s a serious crime.

Perhaps. And now you’re very keen to take our belongings. Yes. I think that’s where I draw the line. I’m afraid that before we hand anything over to you, you’ll have to offer me some proof of wrongdoing. Protocol, you understand.
BEAT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 18
Very well. If you’1ll excuse me, sir, I’1ll see what I can dig
up. Good afternoon.
HE HEADS OUT
I don’t like the sound of that.
I don’t like the sound of any of it.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 19
8. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CORRIDOR
(KEMPTON STRIDING ALONG. ROBOWARDENS FLOAT BY. WARDENS PASS. HE RETRIEVES THE COMMUNICATOR AND CALLS SERAPHIM)
(HISSES) Seraphim?
(DISTORT) Yes, Mr Kempton? Is it done?
(QUIET) Er, not yet, I’m afraid. They were a little on the... stubborn side.

(DISTORT) Do not worry. Their bio-prints are in the system. Give me a few minutes to access those prints. I have a few alterations in mind. By the time you reach central control, I’ll have provided all the ammunition you need.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 20
9. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
COWLEY TALKING TO A VIDEO-LINK
Sir, we haven’t had a staff upgrade in years. Many of my team are old and infirm. Even the Robowardens are getting past it.
(COMMUNICATOR DISTORT) And you think that’s an excuse?
No, no. More an... explanation... We’re just not equipped to deal with a major insurrection.
(DISTORT) It’s not good enough, Cowley. Simply not good enough. Visitor numbers are down.
Well, lots of them are dying, sir. That does rather reduce the total.
(DISTORT) That isn’t what I meant. Rumours are getting out. We've kept it quiet so far, but it won’t be long before word of this goes public. I told you to keep the situation contained!
Customers have friends, sir. Relatives. It’s hard for people to disappear with no one noticing. I’m stuck here, I can’t stop gossip on other planets.
(DISTORT) Can’t stop anything, it appears.
That’s not fair. We don’t want customers dying, we’re doing our best.
(DISTORT) The more corpses pile up the less chance we have of keeping this under our hats. If you can’t stop this, I’1ll find people who can.
I’m sorry?
(DISTORT) Either the problem is eliminated or I’1l have to send in the military.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 21
(FEARFUL) G.H.?
(DISTORT) G.H. They have three heavily armed craft waiting one solar system along. All it would take is a word from me, and they’1l be there. Ready to get things under control.
But the... casualty numbers could be... enormous...
(DISTORT) They already are.
Can’t we try a non-violent solution?

(DISTORT) If that’s what you’d prefer, you know what to do. I’ve given you your instructions, Ms Cowley. I don’t wish to hear from you again, unless it’s to tell me the situation has been neutralised. This is your last chance, remember that. Your very last chance. Good day.
THE LINK CUTS OUT
But — Gah!
SHE THUMPS THE TABLE
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 22
10. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
KEMPTON CHECKS DATA ON A COMPUTER
(MUTTERING) Oh, yes, that is nice. Well done, Seraphim... well done.
COWLEY ENTERS
Damn and blast!
Something the matter, ma’am?
What do you think? Just speaking to head office. They’re not happy with our progress on the... (QUIET) ‘F.P.’ situation.
I have to remind you, you did expect that.
I know I did, but it’s worse than I thought. I really think this time they’1ll want my head.
Oh. That’s not ideal, is it?
No.
Well, if it’s any consolation, ma’am, I believe I might be able to offer some help.
Unless you’ve identified their base, I’m not sure you can.
Not that precisely, but, er.. take a glance at this.
HE TURNS THE COMPUTER ROUND
What am I looking at?
The bio-prints of three unruly customers I picked up earlier. They were behaving in a troublesome manner, so I ran their details through the system. Look what came up.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 23
HE TAPS THE SCREEN
Goodness gracious.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 24
11. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CELL
MEL EXAMINES THE LOCK
Well, it’s a fairly standard computer lock. Shouldn’t be too hard to hack.
Another thing you picked up off Glitz?
When you swan around the galaxy with a confidence artist, your skillset does expand ever so slightly. Shall I - ?
Not yet.
We are escaping though, aren’t we?
Maybe. But it’s still possible this is all a misunderstanding. It wouldn’t do to break out of here if we’re just about to be released. That could lead to all sorts of complications.
DOOR OPENS. COWLEY AND KEMPTON STRIDE IN
Stand to attention.
Though judging by that lady’s expression, a misunderstanding seems somewhat less likely.
THEY RISE
Good afternoon. Head Warden Cowley. I believe you’ve already met my deputy.
Sadly, yes. We’ve had that... ‘pleasure’.
Had the odd conversation. The very odd conversation.
I hope your presence here, Head Warden, means you’re about to offer us a pardon.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 25
Oh, you do, do you, Miss? (LAUGHS)
Although now I’m guessing not.
I’m afraid some rather disturbing information has reached us.
Oh?
Disturbing?
Whatever you’ve heard the Doctor did, it was probably just to save a planet or something...
You’re Free Parkers!
BEAT
I beg your pardon?
(SCOLDING) Kempton -
Free parkers?
Hey! We took your token. We’ll pay just like everyone else.
We don’t mean you intended parking for free. We mean that you’re all of you... ‘Free Parkers’.
Is anyone else following this conversation? Cos I’m not.
Head Warden. You talk as if we should know what Free Parkers are. I’m sorry to break it to you, but we don’t.
Exactly what a Free Parker would say, sir.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 26
Exactly what an innocent man would say too, but don’t let that stop you.
You really shouldn’t bother playing the innocent. We ran your identities through the system. They came up with a red flag. That means we have proof of your allegiances. Categorical proof.
Allegiances to what? Categorical how?
I think you know.
Mate, I think we don’t.
Whatever you’ve found, someone obviously planted it. I mean, you haven’t even asked us for identity details yet!
I think you’ll find we scanned them the moment you arrived, miss.
That’s a bit cheeky.
You’11l forgive me if I’m more concerned with saving lives than with your so-called ‘rights’!
Call me ‘Miss’ again and it’s not my rights you’1ll be worrying about.
Saving lives?
Let’s not get ahead of ourselves, Kempton.
Alright then. If you’re so sure. What exactly is this ‘categorical proof’ you’re talking about? Do we get to see it?
BEAT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 27
(TURNING AWAY, SOTTO) Yes, that is a good question. What is this proof, Kempton?
(SOTTO) I’m afraid it’s classified, Ma’am.
(SOTTO) Classified, Kempton?
(SOTTO) Classified, ma’am.
Classified. Of course it is. (TURNS BACK) The evidence is classified.
Right.
Obviously.
How predictable.
Well, clearly we can’t supply you with confidential information. It might impact upon ongoing investigations.
Yes, and you’d need time to make it up.
That’s an unwarranted accusation. We’re only here to keep our customers safe and to give them an enjoyable parking experience. We’re not in the business of frame-ups.
I’m sure you’re not. Which makes me wonder what’s going on. (SIGHS) So what happens now? Do we go to trial? Plead our case?

Not immediately. As a result of this information, we’re now legally entitled to seize your possessions. If you could hand them over, we’ll search them for incriminating content that could lead to further arrests.
Interesting. And this seizure of possessions would be enacted by the Deputy Head Warden, am I right?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 28
Well, I don’t have the time. I’m a very busy lady.
Yes, I thought as much.
(EXITING) Carry on, Kempton.
Yes, ma’am. — Now: if you’d care to empty your pockets...?
Reckon we might know who planted the evidence now.
What exactly do you want with us, Kempton?
I’m afraid I don’t know what you’re talking about, miss.
BEAT
Well then. It appears we have little choice. Mel, Ace. Pockets!
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 29
12. INT. DUCTING
GORD WORKING ON A COMPUTER. IT BEEPS AND WHIRRS
Work faster, Gord. The Wardens’ network must have some information. No-one can reside here unnoticed.
We manage it.
We have had longer to learn. The Free Parkers are new. Some may have lived with us, but that does not mean they know our ways.
Surely if it were easy to find them, the Wardens would have done so already.
They do not know what they look for. We do.
THE COMPUTER BEEPS
What is that noise?
(READING) They have three of them in custody. Three Free Parkers!
BEAT
My people! To the Wardens’ Lodge. Now!
GORD AND THE OTHERS MOVE OFF
We will fetch them, my queen!
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 30
13. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CELL
KEMPTON TEARS OFF A SCRAP OF PAPER
-.-.- And your receipt. We’ll return your possessions in the fullness of time.
You’d better had.
Don’t try anything.
HE GOES, CLOSING THE DOOR BEHIND HIM.
Mel?
Yes?
Try something.
MEL STARTS TAPPING THE DOOR CONTROLS
Let’s have a go at this lock then...
How long’s that going to take?
THE DOOR POPS OPEN
Does that answer your question? Open sesame.
Excellent. Who needs a sonic screwdriver when you have a Mel? Come along.
THEY HEAD OUT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 31
14. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CORRIDOR) (CONTINUOUS
THEY CREEP OUT
Which way?
Head for the TARDIS. I’1ll meet you there.
You’re giving up on the mystery of the ‘Dream-Spinners’?
For the moment. If it means not getting involved in the mystery of the kleptomaniac parking warden. I’m sure we’ll have a warmer welcome to Dashrah in another time period.
Could hardly be colder. Arrested in ten minutes. Can we never catch a break?
I’ll get our things back. I need my jacket. I’1l catch cold.
We shouldn’t have just handed it over.
Got them off our back, didn’t it? He won’t have got far.
And you’re sure you don’t want our help?
Kempton is hardly the most intimidating opponent we’ve ever encountered. I’ll be fine. (HEADING OFF) Go on. I’1l see you soon.
Alright. But famous last words.
MEL AND ACE RUN OFF IN THE OPPOSITE DIRECTION TO THE DOCTOR.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 32
15. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (ANOTHER CORRIDOR
MEL AND ACE RUNNING
Now you’re sure you remember where we parked?
As I’m sure you’ve forgotten who you’re speaking to. Of course I remember. I always do.
Good point. Just checking. Place this big, I wouldn’t want to get lost —
THE POWER CUTS OUT WITH A SIGH
Uh-oh... Power cut. You reckon they know we’re out?
It’d be an odd way to respond if they did. It’d hinder them just as much as us. You know, the irony is, this would probably have opened the cell door too...
How are we getting out in the dark?
Don’t worry. I remember that route too. This way!
THEY RUN OFF
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 33
16. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
A QUIET ALERT RINGS. SOME PANIC, SOME PEOPLE COLLIDING
What’s the situation, Kempton?
I don’t know, ma’am. I don’t have any monitors to read. We’ve had a total loss of power.
I know. I can see that. Or rather I can’t.
THE ALERT STOPS
Oh come on, even the emergency alarm? This is too much. Get to the back-up generator. If the computers are on, we can at least
figure out what the problem is and repair it.
Yes, ma’am. I understand. I’m on my way.
HE EXITS
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 34
17. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CORRIDOR) (CONTINUOUS

DOCTOR: Head Warden. You talk as if we should know what Free Parkers are. I’m sorry to break it to you, but we don’t.
KEMPTON: Exactly what a Free Parker would say, sir.
KEMPTON: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 26
DOCTOR: Exactly what an innocent man would say too, but don’t let that stop you.
COWLEY: You really shouldn’t bother playing the innocent. We ran your identities through the system. They came up with a red flag. That means we have proof of your allegiances. Categorical proof.
DOCTOR: Allegiances to what? Categorical how?
KEMPTON: I think you know.
ACE: Mate, I think we don’t.
MEL: Whatever you’ve found, someone obviously planted it. I mean, you haven’t even asked us for identity details yet!
KEMPTON: I think you’ll find we scanned them the moment you arrived, miss.
ACE: That’s a bit cheeky.
KEMPTON: You’11l forgive me if I’m more concerned with saving lives than with your so-called ‘rights’!
ACE: Call me ‘Miss’ again and it’s not my rights you’1ll be worrying about.
DOCTOR: Saving lives?
COWLEY: Let’s not get ahead of ourselves, Kempton.
ACE: Alright then. If you’re so sure. What exactly is this ‘categorical proof’ you’re talking about? Do we get to see it?
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 27
COWLEY: (TURNING AWAY, SOTTO) Yes, that is a good question. What is this proof, Kempton?
KEMPTON: (SOTTO) I’m afraid it’s classified, Ma’am.
COWLEY: (SOTTO) Classified, Kempton?
KEMPTON: (SOTTO) Classified, ma’am.
COWLEY: Classified. Of course it is. (TURNS BACK) The evidence is classified.
ACE: Right.
MEL: Obviously.
DOCTOR: How predictable.
COWLEY: Well, clearly we can’t supply you with confidential information. It might impact upon ongoing investigations.
ACE: Yes, and you’d need time to make it up.
COWLEY: That’s an unwarranted accusation. We’re only here to keep our customers safe and to give them an enjoyable parking experience. We’re not in the business of frame-ups.
DOCTOR: I’m sure you’re not. Which makes me wonder what’s going on. (SIGHS) So what happens now? Do we go to trial? Plead our case?
COWLEY: Not immediately. As a result of this information, we’re now legally entitled to seize your possessions. If you could hand them over, we’ll search them for incriminating content that could lead to further arrests.
DOCTOR: Interesting. And this seizure of possessions would be enacted by the Deputy Head Warden, am I right?
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 28
COWLEY: Well, I don’t have the time. I’m a very busy lady.
DOCTOR: Yes, I thought as much.
COWLEY: (EXITING) Carry on, Kempton.
KEMPTON: Yes, ma’am. — Now: if you’d care to empty your pockets...?
ACE: Reckon we might know who planted the evidence now.
MEL: What exactly do you want with us, Kempton?
KEMPTON: I’m afraid I don’t know what you’re talking about, miss.
DOCTOR: Well then. It appears we have little choice. Mel, Ace. Pockets!
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 29
REGINA: Work faster, Gord. The Wardens’ network must have some information. No-one can reside here unnoticed.
TRIBESMAN: We manage it.
REGINA: We have had longer to learn. The Free Parkers are new. Some may have lived with us, but that does not mean they know our ways.
TRIBESMAN: Surely if it were easy to find them, the Wardens would have done so already.
REGINA: They do not know what they look for. We do.
REGINA: What is that noise?
GORD: (READING) They have three of them in custody. Three Free Parkers!
REGINA: My people! To the Wardens’ Lodge. Now!
GORD: We will fetch them, my queen!
GORD: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 30
KEMPTON: -.-.- And your receipt. We’ll return your possessions in the fullness of time.
ACE: You’d better had.
KEMPTON: Don’t try anything.
DOCTOR: Mel?
MEL: Yes?
DOCTOR: Try something.
MEL: Let’s have a go at this lock then...
ACE: How long’s that going to take?
MEL: Does that answer your question? Open sesame.
DOCTOR: Excellent. Who needs a sonic screwdriver when you have a Mel? Come along.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 31
ACE: Which way?
DOCTOR: Head for the TARDIS. I’1ll meet you there.
MEL: You’re giving up on the mystery of the ‘Dream-Spinners’?
DOCTOR: For the moment. If it means not getting involved in the mystery of the kleptomaniac parking warden. I’m sure we’ll have a warmer welcome to Dashrah in another time period.
ACE: Could hardly be colder. Arrested in ten minutes. Can we never catch a break?
DOCTOR: I’ll get our things back. I need my jacket. I’1l catch cold.
MEL: We shouldn’t have just handed it over.
DOCTOR: Got them off our back, didn’t it? He won’t have got far.
ACE: And you’re sure you don’t want our help?
DOCTOR: Kempton is hardly the most intimidating opponent we’ve ever encountered. I’ll be fine. (HEADING OFF) Go on. I’1l see you soon.
MEL: Alright. But famous last words.
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 32
ACE: Now you’re sure you remember where we parked?
MEL: As I’m sure you’ve forgotten who you’re speaking to. Of course I remember. I always do.
ACE: Good point. Just checking. Place this big, I wouldn’t want to get lost —
ACE: Uh-oh... Power cut. You reckon they know we’re out?
MEL: It’d be an odd way to respond if they did. It’d hinder them just as much as us. You know, the irony is, this would probably have opened the cell door too...
ACE: How are we getting out in the dark?
MEL: Don’t worry. I remember that route too. This way!
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 33
COWLEY: What’s the situation, Kempton?
KEMPTON: I don’t know, ma’am. I don’t have any monitors to read. We’ve had a total loss of power.
COWLEY: I know. I can see that. Or rather I can’t.
COWLEY: Oh come on, even the emergency alarm? This is too much. Get to the back-up generator. If the computers are on, we can at least
COWLEY: figure out what the problem is and repair it.
KEMPTON: Yes, ma’am. I understand. I’m on my way.
KEMPTON: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 34
KEMPTON: Seraphim? Seraphim, are you receiving me?
SERAPHIM: (DISTORT) Yes, Kempton?
KEMPTON: There’s a power cut in the Wardens’ Lodge. Was it you?
SERAPHIM: (DISTORT) I don’t know anything about it.
KEMPTON: Well, if it’s not, then [who] — ?
DOCTOR: (STEPPING OUT IN FRONT OF HIM) Who are you talking to, Mr Kempton?
KEMPTON: Ah. Of course. This is your fault, is it, sir?
DOCTOR: You didn’t answer my question.
KEMPTON: It’s none of your concern who I was talking to, it was a private conversation. Are you responsible for the loss of power?
DOCTOR: No, that was as much of a surprise to me as it was to you. not without its uses though. Mr Kempton... I’d like our possessions back.
KEMPTON: With pleasure, sir.
KEMPTON: It’s
KEMPTON: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 35
MEL: See? I told you I knew the way out.
ACE: Did I say I didn’t believe you?
ACE: Whoah! Turn those headlights down, mate, they’re blinding!
GORD: (OFF, BEHIND THE LIGHTS) Those two! They are not in uniform! It is them!
ACE: Oh, what now?
MEL: Is that a trident?
GORD: (OFF) Surrender, Free Parkers!
MEL: Run!
ACE: (RUNNING) When will someone realise we’re not Free Parkers!
MEL: (RUNNING) Whatever they are!
TRIBESMAN: Stop! You shall come with us!
MEL: Oh no we won't!
ACE: Back! This way!
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 36
MEL: (RUNNING) Did you see what they looked like?
ACE: (RUNNING) Not with those lights going...
MEL: (RUNNING) Regular clothing, just very distressed. Tattered suits, that kind of thing. Bit unusual for this place, wouldn’t you say?
ACE: (RUNNING) Some kind of tribe? In a car park?
MEL: Stop! More of them! Up ahead!
ACE: Woah. Apocalypse chic, or what? Who let them out of the thunder
ACE: dome ?
MEL: They’re everywhere!
ACE: Split up!
MEL: (CALLING OUT) If you’re sure! You know where you’re going, right?
ACE: (CALLING BACK) I’'1l wing it. Street smarts, you know!
MEL: Oh, that doesn’t fill me with confidence.
GORD: Stop!
MEL: (RUNNING OFF) No thanks!
MEL: (TO HERSELF) Which way, which way — ? Er... this way...
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 37 (SHE PICKS A ROUTE, RUNS OFF AND IMMEDIATELY THUDS INTO A
ROBOWARDEN: )
MEL: Ah!
ROBOWARDEN: Escapee. Cease perambulation immediately!
MEL: Oh, come on! Tribesmen one way, Robowardens the other —
ROBOWARDEN: (GRABBING HER WRIST) You are under arrest!
MEL: (BEING DRAGGED AWAY) No, no. Ow. That hurts!
TRIBESMAN: No! A Robowarden has her!
GORD: Then we focus on the other. Follow me!
GORD: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 38
ACE: (TO HERSELF) Come on. It’s around here somewhere...
ACE: Whoah!
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) Shh, Ace. We don’t want to attract attention.
ACE: (SOTTO) Blimey. Don’t creep up like that. Do you have to be so sneaky all the time?
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) If I weren't, how could you be sure it was me?
ACE: (SOTTO) Fair point. You got your jacket back.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) I got everything back. Kempton was something of a walkover, offered no fight at all. Which was odd, really.
ACE: (SOTTO) Can’t have thought it was worth the hassle, whatever he was up to.
DOCTOR: (SOTTO) I suppose not. Come along. The TARDIS is this way.
DOCTOR: Where’s Mel? (PATS HIS POCKETS)
ACE: Oh, she’ll have been here ages, I got lost. We split up. There was this bunch of nutters waiting for us. All in rags, and with, like, homemade weapons.
DOCTOR: They must have been the ones who cut the power.
ACE: Makes sense. They seemed to think we were — You alright?
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 39
DOCTOR: Why shouldn’t I be?
ACE: All the patting your pockets. Have you lost something?
DOCTOR: I can’t find the TARDIS key...
ACE: You what?
DOCTOR: It must be here somewhere. I mean, we can always use the spare in —
DOCTOR: No.
ACE: What?
DOCTOR: Where’s she gone? The TARDIS! She was here!
ACE: But that’s impossible. She has to be. Clamped in place, you said.
DOCTOR: I know what I said.
ACE: This isn’t the right bay. It’s a big planet, we took the wrong turning...
DOCTOR: No, Ace. Continent T, Violet Zone, Bay Omicron, Number Eight hundred and three.
ACE: You remembered?
DOCTOR: Of course I remembered! This is where we landed and there’s nothing here now. The TARDIS.. has been stolen!
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 40

elements.text: PART TWO
OPENING THEME
This isn’t the right bay. It’s a big planet, we took the wrong turning...
No, Ace. Continent T, Violet Zone, Bay Omicron, Number Eight
hundred and three.
You remembered?
Of course I remembered! This is where we landed and there’s nothing here now. The TARDIS... has been stolen!
20. INT. PARKING BAY (CONT
THE TRIBE ARE RUNNING UP
And I think we can guess who by...
THE TRIBE ARRIVE
Do not move!
Ah. I presume these are the people who ambushed you.
That’s them.
Surrender, Free Parkers.
Well, in the absence of anything better to do... Why not?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 41
21. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
COWLEY SAT, MEL OPPOSITE
Where are your friends?
I don’t know. If you haven’t caught them, they could be anywhere. They usually are.
Did you know that we weren’t able to find a spaceship where you claim to have parked?
Er.. no. I didn’t, actually. That’s worrying. When did you look?
I ask the questions, Miss Bush!
Of course you do. Oh, knowing the Doctor and Ace they’1l be in the thick of it somewhere.
Eh?

Look, I don’t want to tell you your business, or anything, but wouldn’t it be an idea to wait until the lights were back on before interrogating me? You’re making this an awful lot harder than it needs to be.
We’ve had an issue with the power. Probably your Free Parking friends.
I don’t have Free Parking friends!
Since we’ve no idea when the power’1ll be restored, there’s no point waiting around. Might as well do the interrogation.
Alright. But if we are, maybe explaining what a Free Parker is might give me a chance of convincing you I’m not one.
More delaying tactics? Expecting to get rescued?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 42
No.
That’s why you’re in my office, not the cell. We know you can get out of that.
Yes, but —
(A CLUNK AND A WHIRR. THE POWER COMES BACK ON. COWLEY’S
STARTS UP)
Oh, good, the power’s back. Right. (CLAPS HANDS TOGETHER) Let’s try this again, shall we?
Actually, let’s not.
Oh, come on. If we just wait for my computer to fire up, it
takes its time...
Not if you do this.
Do what?
MEL TAPS THE KEYS. THE COMPUTER IS IMMEDIATELY READY
That.
How did you - ?
And seeing as it’s right here...
SHE TAPS MORE BUTTONS. IT BEEPS
What are you doing?
Oh, it’s alright if I use your computer, isn’t it?
Erm.. I wouldn’t say alright exactly.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 43
Don’t worry. Won’t be two ticks.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 44
22. INT. DUCTING (PASSAGE/TRIBAL LAIR
(ACE AND THE DOCTOR BEING MARCHED THROUGH DUCTING BY THE TRIBE
We gonna be much longer? My feet are killing me.
This way.
We know that. We’re going this way.
I’ll say one thing. This is quite a high standard of ducting. love what you’ve done with the place.
Thank you. Your praise is welcome!
He was being sarcastic.
Oh.
(THEY EMERGE INTO THE TRIBE’S HOME, FIRE FLICKERING, ACTIVITY
AROUND)
Ah. This is more like it. Your standard futuristic undercity. Neon lighting. Gas vents. None of the mod-cons.
Looks like Milton Keynes on a Friday night.
And a fire flickering in the grate too. Lovely.
Welcome to our home, Free Parkers! Welcome to the Tribe of the Lost!
Who’s this?
Mother Regina, Queen of our Tribe!
Course it is.
I
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 45
Regina. You and I will get on much better if you accept one thing. We are not Free Parkers, whatever they might be.
Do not play wise with me, Free Parker. We accessed the Lodge computers. They told us of your allegiances.
That was a stitch up! The Wardens. They’re trying to frame us!
Why would the Wardens do such a thing?
Well, they wouldn’t. Not all of them. It was just one, really.
One?
Kempton, he said his name was.
Mother Regina, I have heard that name. He is the Deputy. He does not let truth stand in the way of an arrest.
See!
BEAT
But you must be Free Parkers. We wish to find their base!
So does everyone, it appears.
We searched the system. The data on you was there, clear as day! We found it in minutes!
Doesn’t that seem awfully easy?
Erm...
Yeah, if everyone’s working so hard to find Free Parkers, don’t you think Free Parkers’d be a little bit harder to find?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 46
BEAT
They may have a point, Mother.
Yes. They may. Blast it! We were so time to stop the Free Parkers’ rule
Ahem. If I might make a suggestion...
BEAT
Speak.
close! I was certain it was of terror!
I am, as it happens, an expert at stopping ‘rules of terror’. I could help you out... for a little more information...
What sort of information?
Well, firstly... who exactly are you?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 47
23. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
MEL TYPES ON THE COMPUTER
I’m really not sure I should be letting you do that.
Oh, you absolutely shouldn’t be. I mean, you’re Head Warden. And I’ve no authority whatsoever.
THE COMPUTER BEEPS
But it seems I might have found something. These are the files about my friends and me, yes?
Erm... yes?
Good.
SHE TAPS SOME MORE
How did you find that so quickly? You’re not a registered user...
I’m very good.
SHE STOPS
Right, there’s a record of the last edit. Lo and behold, that edit was someone marking us with this red flag.
I see.
Now I’m not sure of the relative chronology on Parking, but I’m willing to bet that the time of the edit, here — (TAPS THE SCREEN) - was while we were held in the cell.
Ah... (LOOKS) It was. Actually it’s only a couple of minutes before I saw it.
Well, then. Are you beginning to accept that maybe someone was trying to frame us?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 48
.Llt does start to look like a distinct possibility.
Was it the Deputy Head Warden who showed you the Red Flags?
I think so, yes. Why do you ask?
Because that suggests we’ve found our chief suspect.
Kempton? That’s ridiculous. Why would Kempton want to frame you?
Beats me. We’d never met him before.
He’s a good man. Loyal. An excellent Parking Warden.
Well, he’s up to something.
He’s not. Or if he is, he must have had a good reason. Anyway, that’s not his user code. Whoever was accessing these files was operating from somewhere else entirely.
Really? Hmm. Still think he needs to answer some questions though. Don’t you?
I suppose - That’s a point, actually. He should have been back by now. The emergency generator isn’t that far away... Where’s the man got to?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 49
24. INT. SERAPHIM’S BAY
(A DEEPER LEVEL. DANK, ECHOEY, WATER DRIPPING. EMPTY. KEMPTON
OVER TO SERAPHIM — HER VOICE IS SLIGHTLY SYNTHETIC, BUT COULD PASS FOR HUMAN. ITS SLIGHTLY MUTED AS SHE SPEAKS FROM INSIDE A SHIP)
At last, Kempton.
My apologies, Seraphim. We had a few issues at the Lodge. I got held up.
Did you bring the key?
Of course. Here. It required a little subterfuge, its owner was rather disagreeable.
HE STOPS
Is that it?
Your Robowardens brought it down here.
Not especially impressive, is it? A battered blue box.
You would do well not to criticise.
I’m not criticising, it’s just not what I was expecting.
The outer appearance is unimportant. This box is one of the greatest intelligences ever to have landed on parking.
If you say so.
Open it.
Alright.
KEMPTON PUTS THE KEY IN THE DOOR. TRIES TO TURN IT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 50
(BEAT) Quickly, Kempton.
(EFFORT) I’m going as fast as I can, Seraphim. It’s tricky... it’s not really... turning...
You are an inferior being...
(EFFORT) I’m doing my.. best - (HE GIVES UP) Ah. No. That’s it. Sorry, I don’t think I can do this.
What? You must continue!
It’s not that simple. The lock might look straightforward from there, but.. there’s got to be a.. knack... or a trick, or something. It really isn’t moving.
No one would make a lock that could not be opened.
A particularly powerful intelligence might. If they didn’t want to be disturbed.
BEAT
You met the one who claims ownership of this being?
Well, yes.
He must know the method of access. Bring him here.
Really? How am I supposed to do that? I’ve no idea where he is.
Find a way.
I’m due to initiate the next phase any moment —
Multi-task.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 51
(SIGHS) Of course, Seraphim. Whatever you say, Seraphim. I’11l see what I can do.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 52
25. INT. DUCTING (TRIBAL LAIR
THE DOCTOR, ACE, REGINA AND HER TRIBE SIT AROUND A FIRE
Our ancestors came to this world many centuries ago. They had not intended to settle and yet they did.
Really? Seems an odd place to set up shop.
Like I say, it was not their plan.
So what precisely was their plan?
The First Fathers... the originators... The story tells of them coming here, in a spaceship. They had intended to... ‘see the Sights’ as they put it.
Makes sense.
And, what, they didn’t fancy it when they arrived?
Oh, no. They ‘fancied it’. They travelled to the planet below, precisely as they had wished.
So, yeah... I don’t follow.
They enjoyed their visit. But on their return they were struck by a great and terrible tragedy. A woeful loss almost too painful to bear. (BEAT) They had no idea where they had parked.
Right, I see where this is going.
(SCOLDING) Ace...
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 53

It was the early days of Parking, and the Wardens had underestimated the complexities of a visit. There was no help easily available to the disorientated. No information screens, no clear maps. Many were lost in those early days. Some took weeks to find their spaceships. Some years. Some got so lost they never left at all.
You’re kidding, right?
No. Why should I be?

Societies can develop in very unusual places, Ace. You must know someone who found it hard remembering where they’d parked in an ordinary multi-storey. Obviously it’s harder to remember where you left your ship when the lots are the size of a continent.
Yeah, that’s not the bit I’m struggling with. How did they survive? I mean, this planet’s hardly designed as a comfortable living space.
There must be some accommodation here. For the staff.
Precisely. They had money. At least to start. Enough for food and to barter for lodging.
But it ran out?
All too soon. Our ancestors went roaming through the many levels of this world, forgetting who they were. What they needed they stole or scavenged.
And they just got away with it?
The Wardens tried to stop them. But the Wardens did not expect this, they were not trained. And a planet is a very large place to hide.
So you became a minor nuisance, an itch they couldn’t scratch.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 54
Over the years, our ancestors gathered more of the dispossesed to them. A people built up. My people. My tribe. The Tribe of the Lost. As you see now.
Yes. I do.
This place will not last long. Soon the Wardens will uncover it and we will move on. It shall not be a problem. We are, at heart, nomadic.
And it’s just you? Just the one tribe?

We are the largest. Some smaller groups dwell on other continents. There is a religious sect that broke away. They believe the first lost ship is our creator, and walk this world trying to find it, sure that when it is discovered our true purpose will be revealed.
I’ve seen more unusual ideologies.
And recently a few of our brethren left to pursue their own particular crusade.
Ah. Would I be correct in assuming that they’re known as... ‘Free Parkers’?
You would.
Now we’re getting somewhere. Tell me about them.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 55
26. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
COWLEY AND MEL IN CONFERENCE
The Free Parkers are a group that splintered off from some of the homeless tribes we have living on Parking.
The ones you say call themselves the Tribes of the Lost?
Exactly. After years of us trying to clear them out of the infrastructure, some decided enough was enough. They wanted to be recognised as a native population. They wanted independence.
Like squatter’s rights?
In a nutshell.
They want a free Parking. Of course.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 56
27. INT. DUCTING (TRIBAL LAIR
REGINA CONTINUES HER STORY

Initially they were disorganised. A rag-tag rabble of little import, their actions limited to vandalism or graffiti. Sometimes, a few of our more hot-headed youths would leave to join them, but we never thought them a threat. A danger.
So what changed?
They did. All of a sudden they had a new purpose, a new vigour. Suddenly their activities leapt from mere civic disruption to violence. And murder.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 57
28. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
Murder?
A full blown insurgency. Several spaceships parked here were blown up the moment they took off.
Bombs ?
No. Witness reports suggested that the selfdrive systems made the engines run out of control.
I see.
People are dying. We weren’t prepared for that. We’re just here to provide a service to our customers. Issue the occasional ticket. Not fight a war.
And you’re sure these Free Parkers are responsible?
That’s another thing from the witness reports. The last words the self-drives say before the ships explode. ‘Free Parking’. ‘Free Parking’ over and over again.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 58
29. INT. DUCTING
Sounds pretty conclusive.

They will not stop until they achieve their desire. A free and independent Parking. They care little for who is hurt. The Wardens tar us all with the same brush. Hunt us down as if all are responsible. We wish to find them. Persuade them to cease their atrocities and restore peace to our world.
Then I believe we’re on the same side.
We're big fans of peace. And well good at restoring it.
So first things first. Time to meet them for a chat.
A chat? Ha! The Free Parkers do not ‘chat’!
Yes, I do not wish to seem ungrateful, Doctor, but if we as denizens of this world have been unable to locate them, what chance do two strangers have?
More than you’d think.
What we need is an area visitors rarely use, but the Free Parkers are known to frequent.
The Orange Zone? Bay epsilon? I rarely see ships docked there.
It fits. But why, Doctor? Why do you need to know this?
Because it’s somewhere we can cause an explosion without any casualties. You see, if you’re struggling to find someone, the best idea is not to look. You let them... find you.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 59
30. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE

No information screens, no clear maps. Many were lost in those early days. Some took weeks to find their spaceships. Some years. Some got so lost they never left at all.
ACE: You’re kidding, right?
REGINA: No. Why should I be?
DOCTOR: Societies can develop in very unusual places, Ace. You must know someone who found it hard remembering where they’d parked in an ordinary multi-storey. Obviously it’s harder to remember where you left your ship when the lots are the size of a continent.
ACE: Yeah, that’s not the bit I’m struggling with. How did they survive? I mean, this planet’s hardly designed as a comfortable living space.
DOCTOR: There must be some accommodation here. For the staff.
REGINA: Precisely. They had money. At least to start. Enough for food and to barter for lodging.
DOCTOR: But it ran out?
REGINA: All too soon. Our ancestors went roaming through the many levels of this world, forgetting who they were. What they needed they stole or scavenged.
ACE: And they just got away with it?
REGINA: The Wardens tried to stop them. But the Wardens did not expect this, they were not trained. And a planet is a very large place to hide.
DOCTOR: So you became a minor nuisance, an itch they couldn’t scratch.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 54
REGINA: Over the years, our ancestors gathered more of the dispossesed to them. A people built up. My people. My tribe. The Tribe of the Lost. As you see now.
DOCTOR: Yes. I do.
REGINA: This place will not last long. Soon the Wardens will uncover it and we will move on. It shall not be a problem. We are, at heart, nomadic.
ACE: And it’s just you? Just the one tribe?
REGINA: We are the largest. Some smaller groups dwell on other continents. There is a religious sect that broke away. They believe the first lost ship is our creator, and walk this world trying to find it, sure that when it is discovered our true purpose will be revealed.
DOCTOR: I’ve seen more unusual ideologies.
REGINA: And recently a few of our brethren left to pursue their own particular crusade.
DOCTOR: Ah. Would I be correct in assuming that they’re known as... ‘Free Parkers’?
REGINA: You would.
DOCTOR: Now we’re getting somewhere. Tell me about them.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 55
COWLEY: The Free Parkers are a group that splintered off from some of the homeless tribes we have living on Parking.
MEL: The ones you say call themselves the Tribes of the Lost?
COWLEY: Exactly. After years of us trying to clear them out of the infrastructure, some decided enough was enough. They wanted to be recognised as a native population. They wanted independence.
MEL: Like squatter’s rights?
COWLEY: In a nutshell.
MEL: They want a free Parking. Of course.
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 56
REGINA: Initially they were disorganised. A rag-tag rabble of little import, their actions limited to vandalism or graffiti. Sometimes, a few of our more hot-headed youths would leave to join them, but we never thought them a threat. A danger.
DOCTOR: So what changed?
REGINA: They did. All of a sudden they had a new purpose, a new vigour. Suddenly their activities leapt from mere civic disruption to violence. And murder.
REGINA: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 57
MEL: Murder?
COWLEY: A full blown insurgency. Several spaceships parked here were blown up the moment they took off.
MEL: Bombs ?
COWLEY: No. Witness reports suggested that the selfdrive systems made the engines run out of control.
MEL: I see.
COWLEY: People are dying. We weren’t prepared for that. We’re just here to provide a service to our customers. Issue the occasional ticket. Not fight a war.
MEL: And you’re sure these Free Parkers are responsible?
COWLEY: That’s another thing from the witness reports. The last words the self-drives say before the ships explode. ‘Free Parking’. ‘Free Parking’ over and over again.
COWLEY: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 58
ACE: Sounds pretty conclusive.
REGINA: They will not stop until they achieve their desire. A free and independent Parking. They care little for who is hurt. The Wardens tar us all with the same brush. Hunt us down as if all are responsible. We wish to find them. Persuade them to cease their atrocities and restore peace to our world.
DOCTOR: Then I believe we’re on the same side.
ACE: We're big fans of peace. And well good at restoring it.
DOCTOR: So first things first. Time to meet them for a chat.
GORD: A chat? Ha! The Free Parkers do not ‘chat’!
REGINA: Yes, I do not wish to seem ungrateful, Doctor, but if we as denizens of this world have been unable to locate them, what chance do two strangers have?
ACE: More than you’d think.
DOCTOR: What we need is an area visitors rarely use, but the Free Parkers are known to frequent.
GORD: The Orange Zone? Bay epsilon? I rarely see ships docked there.
REGINA: It fits. But why, Doctor? Why do you need to know this?
DOCTOR: Because it’s somewhere we can cause an explosion without any casualties. You see, if you’re struggling to find someone, the best idea is not to look. You let them... find you.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 59
MEL: The problem’s with the self-drive systems...
COWLEY: As far as we can tell, yes. They drive the engines up to the point of explosion.
MEL: I can’t imagine the Free Parkers could have actually broken into the ships. Not with the level of security you have around here.
COWLEY: It’s one of our guarantees. Your craft will remain where you left it. The doors are stasis locked, and the vehicle clamped. You can’t get back in unless you’ve paid. So potential thieves have no chance at all.
MEL: And with the amount of cameras everywhere, they’d be caught on the CCTV if they even tried.
COWLEY: Exactly.
MEL: So they have to be accessing them remotely. And if that is what they’re doing, we should be able to find some trace of their control signal. Or some entry point in the computer systems.
COWLEY: Should we? Well, I wouldn’t know about that.
MEL: No, but I do. Time to get looking.
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 60
ACE: Hello? Testing, testing, one, two -
DOCTOR: (EARPIECE DISTORT) Coming through loud and clear. Can you hear me?
ACE: Like you’re in the same room.
DOCTOR: (DISTORT) Do you have the target?
ACE: If you mean ‘can I see I the bin?’, yeah, I do.
DOCTOR: (DISTORT) And nobody’s around?
ACE: Not that I can see. Is the tracker working?
DOCTOR: (DISTORT) Seemingly so. Now remember. All sound and no fury, yes?
ACE: I know. When’ve I ever let you down?
DOCTOR: (DISTORT) Do you want me to answer that?
ACE: Probably not.
DOCTOR: (DISTORT) Even with no-one around I’d prefer to avoid
DOCTOR: unnecessary risks.
ACE: Gotcha. Yes. All sound, no fury. On it. Over and out.
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 61
ACE: (A COMPUTER BEEPS IN THE BACKGROUND. THE DOCTOR SWITCHES OFF THE COMMUNICATOR)
REGINA: You trust this woman?
DOCTOR: With my life.
REGINA: And she can do what you say?
DOCTOR: If you want something exploding, Ace should be the first person you call. Keep tracking her.
GORD: We have a strong signal. If they take her, we will know.
DOCTOR: Good.
GORD: And we can watch what happens with our CCTV hack...
DOCTOR: For a nomadic tribe, you’re awfully well equipped.
REGINA: We have to be, to remain free. Doctor, the Robowardens will also hear the explosion. She must keep ahead of them...
DOCTOR: Oh, I wouldn’t worry about that.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL)
ACE: (SOTTO) Three... two... one...
ACE: Still got it! (SHOUTS OUT) Free Parking!
ACE: Page 62
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL)
GORD: She’s on the move.
DOCTOR: Good, let’s see if they take the bait...
DOCTOR: Page 63
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 64
DOCTOR: (ACE RACES ACROSS THE CONCOURSE, THE ALERT FADING INTO THE
BACKGROUND: )
ACE: Free Parking! Free Parking! Free —
ROBOWARDEN: Stop! You have committed an act of civil disobedience.
ACE: Too right. But thanks for telling me. Did you think I wouldn’t
ACE: notice?
ROBOWARDEN: You will come with me.
ACE: (RUNNING OFF) Don’t think so!
ROBOWARDEN: Stop! Or you will be subdued!
ROBOWARDEN: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 65
MEL: You’ve got a new message...
COWLEY: Ooh. Let me see. Maybe Kempton’s signing back in...
MEL: Bit odd him vanishing, isn’t it? Do you still think he’s not involved?
COWLEY: I’d prefer to keep an open mind.
COWLEY: Ah. No. Just a minor fire in an unoccupied zone. A Robowarden’s dealing with it. Sorry. Do continue.
COWLEY: Found anything?
MEL: Maybe. These are the times and places where the ships were sabotaged, yes?
COWLEY: I’1ll take your word for it.
MEL: Well, this spike here — (TAPS SCREEN) — suggests there was a Signal beamed to them shortly before the incident. From the look of the wave, I’d guess a kind of computer virus.
COWLEY: The self-drives were infected?
MEL: And sort of... driven mad, yes.
COWLEY: Well, that gives us the how...
COWLEY: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 66
MEL: It might just give us the who and why too. If I can trace the Signal back —
COWLEY: You could find out who sent it?
MEL: It’s a possibility.
COWLEY: Then do you want to do that then?
MEL: Way ahead of you.
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 67
ACE: Free Parking! Free Parking!
ROBOWARDEN: (OFF) Stop! Stop now!
ACE: (CALLING BACK) Does that ever work? People just stop when you ask them to?
ACE: (A CAR IS APPROACHING, FAST. SUDDENLY, ANOTHER ROBOWARDEN
APPEARS: AHEAD OF ACE, WEAPONS BRISTLING)
ROBOWARDEN: 2: Stop! Or you will be subdued!
ACE: Uh-oh.
DUNNE: Get in! Now!
ACE: Don’t have to ask me twice.
ROBOWARDEN: 2: No! Do not enter that vehicle!
ACE: You robots have way too much faith in asking politely. Step on it, sunshine!
ACE: (DUNNE FLOORS THE ACCELERATOR. THE CAR ROARS AWAY. THE
ROBOWARDEN: BLASTS AT IT)
ROBOWARDEN: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 68
DOCTOR: Looks like they’ve taken the bait.
REGINA: Assuming it is the Free Parkers.
GORD: They are heading for bay Epsilon.
DOCTOR: Then that may be where we’ll find their base. How quickly can we get there?
REGINA: We know many short cuts through the infrastructure of Parking. If bay Epsilon is where they are going, we can easily head them of £...
DOCTOR: Then why are we wasting time discussing it! Let’s go!
REGINA: My people! We have found our foe. We must head for glory!
TRIBE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 69
MEL: Well, I can’t be more specific, but it seems the virus signal is being transmitted from this area...
COWLEY: The lower levels?
MEL: If that’s what they are.
COWLEY: They’re almost entirely disused. The bigger this operation’s got, the more storeys we’ve had to build. You know, better quality bays, improved facilities. A general design upgrade.
MEL: But the lower levels are still accessible?
COWLEY: People still park there, but only really as an overflow. Holiday periods, special events, that kind of thing.
MEL: The Doctor said this was the off-season. Who’d be down there now?
COWLEY: What was that?
MEL: The virus. It’s being transmitted again!
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 70
MEL: (DUNNE’S CAR SCREECHES TO A HALT. HE CLAMBERS OUT, ACE FOLLOWING. HE CROSSES THE BAY)
DUNNE: One of Vartell’s lot are you?
ACE: Never heard of him.
DUNNE: Crosby?
ACE: I’m sort of... freelance.
DUNNE: Well, wherever you’re from, if you really want free Parking, you’d better work with us. You can’t just go blowing up stuff willy-nilly. You’ve got to have a plan!
ACE: Maybe I need someone to teach me. Someone with resources. I mean, not everyone here has a car.
DUNNE: Yeah, we stole that off a trucker. We’re through here. About twenty of us - To enter, flick the third light socket along —
DUNNE: Like that. Come on. You’ll be safe here.
DUNNE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 71
DUNNE: (THEY ENTER. AN ENORMOUS FIGHT’S OCCURRING — THE TRIBE VERSUS THE FREE PARKERS. CONTINUES THROUGHOUT. )
REGINA: There! Dare you think you can fight me, youngling? Yargh!
ACE: Safe? Mate, you need a dictionary.
DUNNE: What in - ?
DUNNE: Ungh!
ACE: Yeah, sorry. It was a trap. And you fell for it. Literally.
DUNNE: The Tribe of the Lost! How did they find us?
DOCTOR: (APPROACHING) Oh, I gave them a little hand with that.
ACE: Bit violent for you, this, isn’t it, Doctor?
DOCTOR: I couldn’t stop them. We turned up and all hell broke loose. I think they had something of a grudge. But now we’ve achieved our objective... (HE CLAPS HIS HANDS AND CALLS OUT) Regina! Regina, please, that will do!
REGINA: What?
DOCTOR: I said that will do. I think you’ve won.
REGINA: I — Yes. You may be right. We need not damage our knuckles further. My people. Enough!
REGINA: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 72
REGINA: Gord. Secure them.
GORD: Yes, my Queen.
GORD: (THE TRIBE DRAG THE FREE PARKERS AWAY AS REGINA APPROACHES THE DOCTOR)
DOCTOR: Join us. Do you recognise this chap?
REGINA: (BEAT) The face is familiar. Dunne, yes? Continent M? I heard you had caught an ill wind.
DUNNE: Did the Wardens put you up to this? You idiots, reckon you’1l get better treatment by dobbing us in? They’1ll come for you next.
REGINA: We take no orders from Wardens!
DOCTOR: We don’t want to fight you.
DUNNE: Looks like it.
DOCTOR: We just want to parley. Make peace!
DUNNE: Didn’t know we were at war.
DOCTOR: We want you to stop blowing up innocent tourists!
DUNNE: Innocent - ? (LAUGHS)
DOCTOR: Oh, yes, very amusing. I know what you’re going to say. That by virtue of coming here, they’ve declared a side, and are no longer innocent —
DUNNE: Not that. You idiots! Those explosions have nothing to do with us!
DUNNE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 73
DOCTOR: Eh?
DUNNE: We’re the ones who are innocent.
ACE: But you’re the Free Parkers, yep?
DUNNE: Oh yeah, that’s us. But we haven’t killed anyone. It’s the Wardens, you see. They’re the ones doing it. The Wardens!
DUNNE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 74
COWLEY: Does this mean another ship is going to blow up?
MEL: Not exactly.
COWLEY: Right. (BEAT) If that’s a virus, it’s spiking an awful lot.
MEL: That’s because it isn’t a virus. Not virus, singular.
COWLEY: Not - ?
MEL: There’s more than one.
COWLEY: Eh?
MEL: They’re targeting multiple ships. We’re about to have quite a few explosions...
COWLEY: But... we can’t be. That’s never happened before, it’s always one at a time.
MEL: Whoever they are, they’ve upped their game. And if I don’t block this signal, we’re going to have plenty of fatalities.
COWLEY: Can you block it?
MEL: I don’t know. I’m trying.
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 75
DUNNE: Why would we start blowing people up? It doesn’t encourage negotiation. We’d been doing well enough with civil disobedience. Non-violent protest.
ACE: Only got your word for that.
REGINA: No, that is true. Some civil liberties groups back an independent Parking. Their campaign was proving successful.
DUNNE: Acts of violence encourage retaliation. Make people angry. All they do is harm our cause.
DOCTOR: You have a point. Peaceful action is usually more successful.
ACE: So what would the Wardens have to gain from killing people? Why would they want to frame you?
DOCTOR: Isn’t it obvious? Because the Free Parking campaign is beginning to prove successful. This way the Wardens damage the Free Parkers’ popularity, and are a handed an opportunity to eliminate them in one fell swoop.
ACE: I dunno. If those Wardens were a bit more organised I might buy it, but that lot’d struggle to blow up a balloon. You said it yourself, Doctor, they’re not exactly formidable.
DOCTOR: A good criminal would hardly present themselves as competent. That could be the perfect disguise.
REGINA: ‘Could be’?
ACE: You’ve got another idea?
DOCTOR: Yes. That something rather more sinister is happening here. And we've only just skimmed the surface.
DOCTOR: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 76
KEMPTON: On the contrary, sir. You’re in very deep waters indeed.
ACE: Kempton!
REGINA: You!
DOCTOR: Oh no.
ACE: So this was the trap!
DUNNE: And you fell for it. You didn’t really think you’d trick me so easily, did you?
KEMPTON: I had Mr Dunne keep a look-out for you. He’s done an excellent job.
DOCTOR: So what happens now? We go back to the Lodge?
KEMPTON: Oh, no, no, sir. We don’t do that.
ACE: But surely you’re still going to arrest us?
KEMPTON: I’m not sure you quite understand. I’m not really a Warden. I’m a Free Parker! I’m the leader of the Free Parkers!
KEMPTON: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 77
COWLEY: Any luck?
MEL: I think I can see the ships the virus is aiming for. I’m trying to put up a firewall, I just hope I’ve enough time to —
COMPUTER: (VOICE A DIGITISED SERAPHIM) Free Parking.
MEL: (STOPS TYPING) Uh-oh.
COMPUTER: Free Parking.
COWLEY: But this computer doesn’t have a voice interface. (BEAT)
MEL: I think we may have been spotted.
COMPUTER: Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
COWLEY: It doesn’t have a self-drive either... (TAPS HER COMPUTER) But it is getting very hot...
MEL: Get back!
MEL: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 78
DOCTOR: Not really a Warden?
DUNNE: We put him in the Lodge!
ACE: Eh?
DOCTOR: What?
KEMPTON: Obviously, the Free Parkers couldn’t have lasted this long without a spy. I was born on this planet! I’m a tribesman of Parking!
ACE: You’re one of the Lost? Don’t sound like it.
KEMPTON: Naturally, I had to adopt the more formal tones of the Wardens in order for my subterfuge to succeed, but my ancestors mislaid their ship on this world many decades ago. I’m as much a tribesman as anyone here.
DUNNE: He joined the movement! Then infiltrated the lodge!
DOCTOR: Tribesman turned warden?
ACE: Other way round, more like. I don’t buy it.
KEMPTON: Mother Regina, please. Tell them! You know me.
ACE: Regina?
REGINA: I — I believe he speaks the truth, Doctor, yes. I know this man!
DOCTOR: You do?
REGINA: Of course. This pilgrim left our tribe some years back.
REGINA: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 79
DOCTOR: Pilgrim?
REGINA: Back when he was with the tribe he was something of a runt. I did not think ever to see him again.
KEMPTON: You see, sir? Mother Regina knows I’m being honest. If you don’t trust me, maybe you’1l trust her.
DOCTOR: I don’t know...
P.A. SYSTEM: Free Parking!
DUNNE: No.
REGINA: Was that the P.A. system?
DOCTOR: Sounded like it.
ACE: What’s happening?
REGINA: Another attack.
KEMPTON: Oh dear.
P.A. SYSTEM: Free Parking! Free Parking! (REPEAT UNDER)
DOCTOR: More than just one attack, from the sound of things...
ACE: That’s more than a single ship!
FURTHER: P.A. SYSTEMS/COMPUTERS/SELF-DRIVES: (DISTANT ECHO) Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
ACE: Way more!
ACE: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 80
DUNNE: D’you see? D’you see? Still reckon we’re responsible?
DOCTOR: I’m not sure it matters what I think. Someone’s committing the biggest mass murder this planet’s ever seen! Parking has declared war!
P.A. SYSTEMS: Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
P.A. SYSTEMS: (THE DISTANT VOICES BUILD INTO A CACOPHONY — AND THEN A SERIES OF ALMIGHTY EXPLOSIONS LEADING INTO: )
P.A. SYSTEMS: #227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 81

elements.text: PART THREE
OPENING THEME
D’you see? D’you see? Still reckon we’re responsible?
I’m not sure it matters what I think. Someone’s committing the biggest mass murder this planet’s ever seen! Parking declared war!
Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
(THE DISTANT VOICES BUILD INTO A CACOPHONY — AND THEN A SERIES OF ALMIGHTY EXPLOSIONS )
46. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (COWLEY’S OFFICE
(THE COMPUTER FIZZES AND SPARKS. THE EXPLOSIONS ARE AUDIBLE OUTSIDE)
COUGHING
Are you alright?
Just about. Fortunately there’s only so much exploding a small computer can do...
THE EXPLOSIONS CONTINUE OUTSIDE
Speaking of explosions, you hear that?
That’s an awful lot of them...
Exactly. Sounds like a declaration of hostilities. Are there other computers in the Lodge?
In central control.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 82
Then we need to see if whoever attacked us got them too.
SHE HEADS OUT
But technically you’re still under — Oh never mind.
FOLLOWS MEL OUT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 83
47. INT. CONCOURSE
PANIC. TOURISTS RUN AROUND SCREAMING AND CRYING
What’s happening?/Let’s get out of here!/Run for your lives!
ETC
Remain calm. Parking is experiencing technical difficulties.
A SPACESHIP RISES NEARBY
Please do not leave. Normal working order will be restored shortly. (BEAT) Spaceship in bay 358, you are not authorised to depart.
(IN THE SHIP) I’m not staying here!
(IN THE SHIP) Free Parking! Free Parking! Free Parking!
(IN THE SHIP) What in - ?
THE SHIP EXPLODES
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 84
48. INT. FREE PARKERS’ BASE
(DUNNE DARTS IN. OUTSIDE, EXPLOSIONS ECHO. THE FREE PARKING
ARE REPEATED OVER P.A. SYSTEMS AND SELFDRIVES )
Well, Mr Dunne? What’s happening?
Chaos! It’s chaos out there! There are alarms going off all over the place. Dozens of ships just... gone. Everyone’s panicking.
Of course they are. Must have been a massacre!
One that’s still going on from the sound of things.
They will blame us!
We’ve got to stop it!
Yes, but how?
You might not know, sir. But I do.
You?
Doctor, surely you do not still distrust him! He was with us when the attacks took place!
I know. But I don’t put anything past this man. I suspect he’s playing a very clever game.
Which is why, with the greatest of respect, you’re not going to be part of the solution. (HE DRAWS A GUN) Hands in the air, please.
Did you have a gun before?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 85
It’s new. Mr Dunne, if you wouldn’t mind freeing the rest of the movement, then locking this lot up, that would be appreciated.
Sure.
HE LEAVES
I said in the air, please. You too, Mother Regina. And the rest of your tribe.
Us? But we are your people!
I’m afraid after siding with these two I’m not sure I can trust you.
Gah!
What are you planning on doing?
Well, sir, the Wardens have taken their schemes to the next level. The only way to stop things is to wipe them out. Completely.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 86
49. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CONTROL
(PANIC. ALARMS BLARING EVERYWHERE. COMPUTERS PINGING. MEL AND
RUN IN)
Twenty down! Thirty down!/Try to keep everyone calm/Casualty numbers — rising!/Have the Robowardens contain the situation/What on Parking are we supposed to do! (ETC)
Alright, everybody, calm down! I’m here.
THE WARDENS DON’T CALM DOWN
I suppose that was a long shot.
MEL RACES TO A COMPUTER TERMINAL
At least the computers are still active.
SHE STARTS TYPING. COWLEY DOES THE SAME ON ANOTHER TERMINAL
I can send a signal out...
A signal?
I have to accept that this situation exceeds my capabilities. I need help...
Help? You can’t mean —
Galactic Heritage.
You really think that’1ll calm things down?
Can’t make them worse, can it?
I wouldn’t bet on that.
COWLEY FINISHES
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 87
There. Message sent. Fingers crossed. (BEAT) What are you doing?
(STOPS TYPING) Getting up to speed. People are trying to abandon Parking. Just getting in their ships and flying off.
Which is... alright, surely? Gets them out of harm’s way.
Not really, the ships explode on launch.
Oh.
Maybe if I lock down the planet. (SHE STARTS TYPING AGAIN) Seal the bays. If the ships can’t take off, they can’t blow up.
That sounds good.
It would be if I could do it. It’s proving rather harder than I’d expected. (STOPS TYPING) You know, I think someone’s put an override in the system to make it impossible. They’re way ahead of us.
They always have been.
So we need something else, something they won’t have thought of... (BEAT) The teleport.
What about it?
Would we be able to use the teleport to send the remaining visitors down to Dashrah? They’d be safe there.
Um... I don’t see why not.
Then it’s worth a try. Where are the teleport controls?
Well, not here, they’re at the teleport station.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 88
So to get to them we’re going to have to head through the concourse? And all the explosions?
I’m afraid so.
BEAT
Better get on with it then.
THEY HEAD OUT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 89
50. INT. FREE PARKERS’ BASE
DUNNE APPROACHES KEMPTON
They’re locked up.

COWLEY: Any news on the override?
MEL: Looks like our saboteur may have overriden that too. I might be able to get around it, with a little time —
COWLEY: No! The inner doors!
WARDENS: Argh! Ugh! (COUGHING) (ETC)
MEL: Except now it looks like time might be in short supply.
FREE: PARKING! FREE PARKING! FREE PARKING!
