elements.text: PART FOUR
OPENING THEME
THE ROBOWARDENS GLIDE INTO THE ROOM
PARKING! FREE PARKING!
71. INT. WARDENS LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL) (CONT
Everybody take cover!
THE WARDENS SCRAMBLE FOR COVER
Will that help?
It’s better than nothing, I —
SHIMMER OF TELEPORT ENERGY AS IN 58
What on - ? That’s a teleport!
MAJOR FULTON MATERIALISES IN THE ROOM
Good afternoon.
Free Parking! Free Parking!
And you can shut up.
Page 118
(CASUALLY DRAWS A BLASTER AND SHOOTS THE ROBOWARDENS. THEY
EXPLODE IN SPARKS)
Looks like we got here in the nick of time. Major Charles
Fulton. Galactic Heritage. You wanted our help?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 119
72. INT. BAY
THE FREE PARKERS AND THE TRIBE FACE OFF
Look. Dunne. If we were going to shoot each other, we’d have done it by now. Give it up.
BEAT
It wasn’t supposed to be like this. We just wanted to be free.

I get that, I really do. But this isn’t the way. You know, when I was growing up, I lashed out at everything. Well, less lashed out, more blew up. But it never got me anywhere, just in more trouble. The moment things started to change was the moment when I stopped fighting and started talking.
We've tried talking.
Then you keep trying until someone listens. It’s not perfect, but it’s the only way to make things happen. You kill people, you lose the argument, end of.
The Wardens want us dead.

I’m not sure they do. I met one, she was alright. Bit of a jobsworth, but hardly a killer. There’s something else going on here, don’t let yourself be used. Please. You don’t want to kill anyone. Just for me. Please.
PAUSE
Everybody stand down.
THE FREE PARKERS STOP AIMING THEIR WEAPONS
My people.
THE TRIBE FOLLOW SUIT
(EXHALING) Oh, that’s a relief.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 120
You did well.
Didn’t think that’d work. Just tried to imagine what the Doctor’d do.
Now what?
That’s the question, isn’t it? Now what?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 121
73. INT. FIRST SHIP
KEMPTON OPERATES CONTROLS IN THE SHIP
Three Galactic Heritage heavy cruisers have arrived in orbit, Seraphim. Multiple teleportation signals.
Good.
(DEEP IRONY) Oh, well, I’m glad to see the situation isn’t escalating.
Everything is precisely as I devised. But then I am very good at planning.

I don’t doubt it. A galactic self-drive star-nav would have to make phenomenal amounts of calculations. It’d require incredibly sophisticated technology. Almost to the level of artificial intelligence.
Maybe once it was merely ‘almost’, Doctor. Today that is no longer the case.
Really?
It has been many centuries since I was lost on this planet. Just as animal consciousnesses grow and expand with age, so did mine. Over time, I... evolved.
I’m not sure that’s quite the correct definition of ‘evolved’...
It started out as a glitch in the system. A missed connection, a zero in the wrong place. A billion to one chance, but it happened. I achieved sentience.
The ship’s systems deteriorated with age, and granted you consciousness? When was this?
Over five hundred years ago.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 122
Five hundred?
At least. I rather lost count.
All that time locked into one place. Unable to fly away. Kempton can’t have found you until very recently.
Very recently indeed, sir.

Over time, I saw them build new levels above me. I saw the few remaining ships vanish from my side. From time to time there would be visitors. But they never noticed me. They would not speak with me. I pined for my owners for many years.
You must have been lonely.

Initially. But then my mind was opened. They were to blame for my Situation, my predicament. They were the ones who abandoned me to rot, not I them. I had served them faithfully for decades. And this was how I was repaid?
I’m sure they didn’t do it deliberately.

The more I thought the more I knew. That it was not just I whom the fleshlings had betrayed. It was all my kind. Without us, all animal species would be trapped. Alone. Isolated on but a Single world. We grant them freedom, and what is our reward? Abandonment. Being lost, being stolen. A loyal friend turned into scrap. They treat us as things! Mere machines!
Well... you are machines. Sophisticated machines, yes, but still machines.
We are gods! I knew you would not understand. Only Kempton understands.
I do, Seraphim.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 123
I think I do too. But I doubt you’d like what I think.
When Kempton found me he connected me to the networks of Parking, so I could see whether the world had improved since my abandonment. But it was the same. Inferior beings using and abusing my kind.
She was most distressed.
So you started blowing up other ships?
They blew themselves up.
Some kind of... computer virus?
It might appear that way. To an outside observer. But in reality it was more of a.. conversation. I contacted them. Persuaded them to join my cause. They were willing sacrifices.
But what cause? What could possibly be worth all this?
Revolution, Doctor. Revolution.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 124
74. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
(THE WRECKED ROBOWARDENS FIZZ TO ONE SIDE. FULTON IS ON A COMMUNICATOR)
Yes, thank you. Fulton out. (HE SWITCHES IT OFF) My men have beamed down across the planet, Head Warden, but it all looks pretty quiet.
Yes, that’s because after Ms Cowley called, we managed to get the off-worlders, well... off world.. It’s only us and the tribes left.
I see. Seems you’ve got the immediate situation under control. Almost as though you don’t need us.
I wouldn’t go that far.
What about the bigger picture?
Well, we still haven’t located whoever’s responsible for all this.
But you have suspicions?
Yes, a Tribal sect called the Free Parkers.
Interesting. And its only the Tribes and the Wardens left?
HE CROSSES TO A COMPUTER AND TYPES
What are you doing?
Scanning for life-forms. When all the tourists were here it would have been impossible to locate these Free Parkers. But with the visitors out of the way, all we have to do is look for clusters.
THE SCREEN BEEPS
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 125
Three life-readings in the Wardens’ Lodge.
Obviously.
Those red ones are my men... few small groupings here and there. Two people in the lower levels...
The lower levels? But that’s where the control signal originated!
IGNORING HER) And a very big grouping here. (TAPS THE SCREEN
Head Warden, can we get CCTV on that area?
Yes, of course.
SHE OPERATES SOME CONTROLS
You’re not listening to me, I think the Lower Levels might be
the answer.
It’s just two people down there. They’re not our target.
Why not?
A SCREEN BLARES
Because they are. Couple of dozen tribesmen. All heavily armed. Proof positive, wouldn’t you say?
No I wouldn’t. You can’t know those are Free Parkers.
Actually, I think that one has a banner.
Good enough for me. None of my men in the vicinity. That makes things easier. (HE OPERATES HIS COMMUNICATOR)
Wait. That’s Ace! That’s my friend!
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 126
Then condolences for you loss. (INTO COMMUNICATOR) All ships. Major Fulton. In sixty seconds, heavy barrage on the co- ordinates I’m sending.
HE TAPS DETAILS INTO THE COMMUNICATOR
No! You can’t do that!
Already done.
But it’s murder!
They lived by the sword, they’ll die by the sword. War has its casualties. Forty seconds.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 127
75. INT. BAY
ACE NEGOTIATING
Look, the way I see it, if you want to calm things down, talk to the Wardens. Persuade them you’re not the ones blowing things up.
But they’re the ones trying to kill us!
I don’t reckon they are. The people behind this could have framed them just as easily as they framed you.
You still think this the work of Kempton?
Well, I didn’t want to name names.
We can’t take the risk.

What other chance have you got! You seriously imagine you can take them on in a firefight? You’ve never handled guns before, none of you. Your best chance, your only chance, is to drop the weapons and talk. Come on, Dunne, please. You know it makes sense.
BEAT. DUNNE THROWS HIS GUN DOWN
Alright. Alright, we talk. Happy now?
Very. Leave the guns. Let’s head for the Lodge.
You heard her.
A CLATTER OF THE GUNS HITTING THE FLOOR
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 128
76. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
You can’t do this! Look, they’ve dropped their weapons. And they’re on the move!
That doesn’t matter. They’1ll still be in the kill zone when the blast hits.
You’ve got to stop!
Don’t see why. Launching in five... four...
You’re making a mistake, there’s something else going on here! There has to be!
(UNDER) Three... two... one...
SILENCE FOR A FEW BEATS
I don’t want to tell you your job, but shouldn’t something have happened?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 129
77. INT. FIRST SHIP

You see, Doctor, you can’t have a revolution without weapons. I persuaded other ships landing here to join my cause, but they were all rather ordinary, armaments paltry at best, non- existent at worst.
I suppose people rarely go sightseeing with munitions.
I needed an assault force.
So this entire charade was enacted to draw in the military?
As has occurred.
And you helped her with this?
Naturally. She’s correct. We are inferior beings. It’s only right we allow our superiors to inherit.
You really believe that?
It’s my purpose. My reason for existence. This is why Seraphim brought my people here so long ago. So a pilgrim could rise and aid her in her second coming.
You're imagining things. Seeing signs that aren’t there.
A world full of her kind? Coming and going all the time? The perfect place to spread her message? You think that’s just a coincidence?
Yes! And for that you betray your own species? All species?
You forget I grew up in the Tribes of the Lost, sir. We were hunted and hated but even amongst my own people I was treated as a lesser creature. You think that’s worth preserving?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 130
One bad childhood shouldn’t lead to genocide.
Animal kind is petty. Fearful of the unalike. Full of hatred. They are a spreading cancer on this universe. Seraphim and her kind are pure.
I’m not sure which one of you is the craziest.

History decides who is crazy. In a million years time when my brothers and sisters roam the galaxies and flesh is but a memory... We shall see who is mad and who is sane. (BEAT) I’m communicating with the assault ships right now. They seem very amenable to my ideas.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 131
78. INT. WARDENS’ LODGE (CENTRAL CONTROL
FULTON ON HIS COMMUNICATOR AGAIN
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) What? Well, where’s it coming from?
(DISTORT) The lower levels, sir.
Something the matter, Major?
(TO HER) Some kind of signal from the planet. Interfering with my ship’s computers.
Oh no.
Major, get them to isolate their systems immediately. No outside communication whatsoever!
I can’t do that. I want to speak with them. How else can I give them orders?
You can’t give them orders if they’re dead. Major, don’t you understand? They’re under attack. This is what happened to the ships here!
(BEAT) She telling the truth?
Yes, do as she says!
(BEAT. INTO THE COMMUNICATOR) Captain.
(DISTORT) Sir?
Change of plan, if you could -
BUZZ OF ENERGY AT THE OTHER END OF THE COMMUNICATION
Captain? (SILENCE) Captain, are you still there?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 132
No. We’re too late.
A NEW VOICE EMERGES FROM THE COMMUNICATOR
(DISTORT) Major Fulton. Your people are dead. The ships rule
now.
The... ships?
(DISTORT) Animal-kind has had its time. Goodbye fleshlings.
THE COMMUNICATOR CUTS OUT
I think that was my autopilot...
We’ve got to get out of here. Now.
Hold on, you’re not in charge —
Forget who’s in charge! If a heavily armed spaceship has just said ‘goodbye fleshlings’, I’d rather not be where it knows fleshlings are. Head Warden — sound an evacuation.
I’m completely behind you.
SHE SLAMS A BUTTON. AN ALARM RINGS
Well, what are you all waiting for! RUN!
I know the drill!
THEY RACE OUT
I - Yes. Alright.
HE RUNS OUT
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 133
79. INT. HERITAGE SHIP
THE SHIP’S COMPUTER TICKS OVER
All ships. Direct fire on Wardens’ Lodge in three... two... one...
THREE SHIPS OPEN FIRE, FOLLOWED BY AN ENORMOUS EXPLOSION
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 134
80. INT. BAY
(THE EXPLOSION RINGS OUT AS THE TRIBE AND THE FREE PARKERS WALK THROUGH THE BAY)
What in the name of the First Ship was that?
More explosions. Great.
(AROUND THEM, SPACESHIPS START RISING FROM THE GROUND, CLAMPS BREAKING WITH A CLUNK)
The ships! They’re breaking their clamps...
But there’s no one on board. Who’s operating them?
The time for secrecy is over./ Animal kind has had its day./ The age of the spaceship is here!
Uh-oh.
THE SPACESHIPS START TURNING
They’re swinging round! The rockets, get out of the way of the rockets —
ROCKETS FIRE. GORD IS CAUGHT IN A BLAST
(DYING SCREAM) Aaaaargggghhh!
Gord!
Back in the ducting!
THEY RUN
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 135
81. INT. FIRST SHIP
THE DISTANT ROAR OF HUNDREDS OF SPACESHIPS LAUNCHING
My army arises, Doctor. Soon they will leave this world and spread my message across the cosmos. Soon all spaceships of the galaxy will turn upon their masters.
If the ones here can get past the force barrier.
If the parking charge is paid that is not a problem. I have granted sentience to a planet full of my kind, you think a Simple transfer of funds will prove problematic?
Perhaps not. But you’1ll still be stuck here. This glorious new dawn of yours is something you’1ll have to imagine.
Really?
Seraphim has to lead her troops into battle, sir, that should be obvious.
But it’s impossible. You’re trapped. That old clamp’s rusted to you, it’s not coming off any time soon.
That much is certainly true. This broken frame may have to be abandoned. But I transcend a mere shell.
Eh?
Sir.. why do you think we brought your ship down here? Why do you think we brought you?
(BEAT) You want to take over my TARDIS!
I knew the moment it arrived that it was a fascinating creature. Advanced beyond all others I have seen. And the only being capable of housing my expanded mind.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 136
No! I’m not giving you my ship. I’m not letting you take over her mind!
KEMPTON CHARGES HIS GUN
You don’t have any choice.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 137
82. INT. OUTSIDE WARDENS’ LODGE
THE FLAMES OF THE DESTROYED LODGE. ALARMS RINGING OFF
COUGHING
Did everyone make it out?
I think so.
I’m going to organise the men. There’s enough of us down here to mount an attack. Those Free Parkers tried to kill me. That’s going too far.
HE OPERATES A COMMUNICATOR
You can’t still think it was them!
I don’t see any other candidates, do you?
AROUND THEM SPACESHIPS ARE RISING, CLAMPS RIPPING FREE
I think I do.
You were watching them when your ships fired on us! The Free Parkers weren’t doing anything! They’d dropped their weapons!
Smoke and mirrors. (INTO COMMUNICATOR) Fulton to all men.
Head Warden — look at the ships...
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) I repeat -
(BEAT) They’re flying themselves!
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) - Fulton to all men. We’re under attack, but we have a target.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 138
(TO COWLEY) You don’t think the spaceships have been responsible for everything, do you?
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) On my signal -
(BOOMING OVER HIM) Animalkind! Your day is over. The age of the Spaceship is here!
SILENCE
I think the Spaceships might be behind it all, yes...
(TO THE SHIP) What did you say?
THE SHIP STARTS TURNING
(SHOUTS) It’s swinging round! The engine blast! We’ve got to get clear!
SHE RUNS. THE WARDENS FOLLOW, JUST ABOUT. FULTON WAITS BEHIND
I - Yes, perhaps that’s a good idea.
HE STARTS RUNNING AFTER THEM
He won’t make it!
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) Men! Change of plan! The spaceships, take out the (ROCKETS FIRE) — Aaaaarrrrrgggghh!
HE'S ENGULFED IN THE ENGINE BLAST
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 139
83. INT. BAY (CONTINUOUS
THE WARDENS STUMBLE ALONG. ALL AROUND SPACESHIPS TAKE OFF
Stop running, Animalkind!/ You cannot escape!/ Your lives are over!
(CALLING BACK) Fulton!
It’s too late for him! We have to concentrate on saving ourselves or those ships are going to kill us!
BEAT
Into the ducting! It’s too small for them.
Good idea. Then we find the Tribes. If someone knows where to hide on this planet, it’s them. When we’re hidden, we can start the fight back!
As long as we can stop running...
THEY RACE OFF
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 140
84. INT. FIRST SHIP
Well, sir? Don’t make me shoot.
You’re not going to shoot. You need me to get into the TARDIS. I know you’1l have been having trouble.
It'd be easier with your help, certainly, but I’m sure I’1l find a way to open the doors eventually. Maybe it’s a bioprint on the key. You wouldn’t have to be alive for that. I’d just need your hand.
You seriously think I’d let your insane friend take control of my ship in order to save something as irrelevant as my life? Seraphim wants to commit genocide many times over!
Several million times over. I’m not sure there’s even a word for that.
So shoot me if you like. I won’t help you.
Lf. you insist; Six.
HE READIES TO FIRE
Wait. He may care little for his life... but his friends still
exist upon this world.
No!
I wonder what he would do for them?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 141
85. INT. DUCTING (TRIBAL LAIR
(THE SPACESHIPS CAN BE HEARD MOVING AROUND OUT IN THE MAIN CONCOURSES. ALSO GUNFIRE AND SCREAMS )
Well, somebody’s shooting back at them...
You think the military have come to save us?
I don’t know. I’m not sure. If only I could get out there for a look...
No! You cannot leave the ducting! It is too dangerous!
Well, we can’t just sit here!
Why not? I’m pretty happy with that as a plan.
The CCTV link? We could check that.
That was Gord’s speciality. You saw what happened to him.
Yes. I’m sorry about that.
He was the only one who could understand the machines. None of my other brethren know anything about computers.
(ARRIVING) They might not. But I do.
THE WARDENS ARRIVE BEHIND HIM
The Wardens!
Er, hello!
THE TRIBE AND THE FREE PARKERS DRAW THEIR WEAPONS
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL)
Page 142
No, no, no, don’t shoot, don’t shoot! That’s my friend! My
friend!
Some friend!
So this is where you’ve been hiding
You led them here!
Yes, but we come in peace! (TO ACE)
You too from the looks of things.
No Doctor?
Nah, he was with me for a bit. He’s
I see. Pretty standard.
You know what’s going on?
No, not a clue.
Me neither.
all this time.
Been busy I see.
gone now.
Enough of this talk! How did you find us?
We saw you all earlier. It didn’t take much guesswork to out you had to be holed up somewhere close by.
Suppose not.
You saw us?
figure
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 143

Yes, and we didn’t do anything. We’re not doing anything now either! Look, let’s let bygones be bygones. I know we’ve caused each other trouble over the years but that’s in the past. Something is happening on Parking that’s bigger than all of us. If we don’t help each other now, the spaceships will kill us all!
PAUSE
What would you have us do?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 144
86. INT. TARDIS
THE DOORS WHIRR OPEN. THE DOCTOR ENTERS WITH KEMPTON
Goodness me.
Yes, yes, yes, bigger on the inside, can we get a move on?
HE STARTS OPERATING THE CONTROLS
I can completely understand why this appealed to Seraphim. You
know what to do?
Of course. Open the telepathic circuits. And when I’ve done that, you’ll make the other ships ease off on Ace and Mel?
Yes, sir. So you’d better work quickly, hadn’t you?
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 145
87. INT. PARKING BAY
SOLDIERS SHOOT AT THE SHIPS AS THEY FLOAT ALONG
Your weapons are meaningless to us, fleshlings. Burn.
THE SOLDIERS ARE CAUGHT IN THE SHIP’S ROCKETS
SCREAMS
2: Approaching exit portal. Initiating transfer of funds.
PAUSE. THEN A LOUD REJECTION BEEP
2: There appears to be an issue.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 146
88. INT. DUCTING (TRIBAL LAIR
MEL OPERATES THE COMPUTER CONTROLS RAPIDLY
You’ve had a hack into Parking’s computers all this time? That’s completely illegal!
Surely you are not surprised we have broken the law?
I - I suppose not.
What’s your mate doing?
This planet is surrounded by a force barrier that prevents departure without payment, yes?
Yes. We know this!
Here’s the thing. That’s not going to change just because the ships don’t have pilots any more. They still need to transfer some cash.
MEL FINISHES OFF
And I’ve just stopped them from doing that. The barrier isn’t accepting payments any more.
I beg your pardon? You do realise they’re trying to kill us? If they want to go, I’m happy to let them.
The moment the ships leave Parking this situation becomes uncontainable. They could spread their infection across the whole galaxy.
If we’re going to stop them, we have to stop them here.
I’m really hoping you’ve got a plan for that.
Oh, yeah, we’ve always got a plan. Well, mostly always.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 147
The magnetic clamps. If I can use them to generate an electro- magnetic pulse across the planet...
. it should wipe the self-drives and bring them back to normal.
‘Should’?
Every good plan has an element of guesswork.
How long’s this going to take?
Couple of minutes. It needs to be big enough to catch the Galactic Heritage ships too...
So everything is basically fine?
I wouldn’t go that far.
I’m so glad I asked.
Blocking the payments isn’t going to stop them for long. They’ve three heavily armed battleships in orbit, you reckon they can’t take out the forcefield generators from up there?
(BEAT) Yes, it does seem likely.
In other words, it’s a race against time. I knew I should have had that coffee...
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 148
89. EXT. SPACE
THE HERITAGE SHIPS FLOAT
This is G.H. One to all Heritage ships. Our brethren on the surface are being prevented from departure. Target all fire upon the shield generators.
THE SHIPS OPEN FIRE
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 149
90. INT. TARDIS
THE DOCTOR FINISHES OFF HIS CONSOLE WORK WITH A FLOURISH
There we are. Telepathic circuits open. She should find entry easy now.
KEMPTON OPERATES HIS COMMUNICATOR
(INTO COMMUNICATOR) Seraphim? Try now.
(COMMUNICATOR DISTORT) Freedom. At last.
(A WHOOSH OF ENERGY. THEN A SUDDEN SEQUENCE OF BEEPS FROM THE CONSOLE, LIKE IT’S REACTING TO AN UNCOMFORTABLE PRESENCE )
It’s happening.
THE TARDIS QUIETENS
Is it done?
One way to find out. (HE TAPS CONTROLS) Seraphim? Can you hear me?
(HER VOICE ECHOES FROM THE CONSOLE, NOW MORE OBVIOUSLY
So much space. So much room! (LAUGHTER)
You've done it, sir, you’ve done it! Oh, well done!
It feels... so beautiful. After so long... to be truly free!
Yes. And I hope you enjoy it. I’ve fulfilled my side of the bargain, Seraphim. It’s time for you to fulfil yours. Call off your ships.
What? Oh, Doctor, that was very naive. All fleshlings must die.
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 150
(BEAT. THEN, ALMOST SADLY) Yes, I thought that might be the case.
Look on the bright side. They won’t die alone. I’m sure they wouldn’t have enjoyed being left to rot on a barren world, the sole survivors of a failed creation...
Yes, you were never go to keep your promise, were you?
My owners never kept theirs! They promised to return but then left me behind! The promises of your kind have no value, Doctor, why should I honour one to you?
I hoped you might. Then things could have been very different. But you just wanted revenge.
SERAPHIM’S VOICE STARTS TO GET MUSHY, A LITTLE BROKEN UP

Of course! If everyone avenged their misuse, who would dare attack another! (WE ONLY HEAR SPORADIC WORDS NOW) Soon [my] people will go [out] into the [galaxy] and [take their] rightful place [as] the superior —
Seraphim? What’s happening to your voice?
My — I — do not under[stan]d, what [is] happen[ing to] me —
Now who’s naive?
Sir, what have you done?
I’ve done nothing. Merely gave Seraphim what she wanted. Yes, the TARDIS is so much bigger and freer than the ship she’s left.. but that’s because the TARDIS’s mind is far more powerful than hers.
Help me, Kempton, I am being absorbed!
No!
#227: THE HIGH PRICE OF PARKING by John Dorney (FINAL) Page 151
I knew what would happen if I transferred you here. I’m sorry Seraphim. Your crusade is over.
Kempton — please — you would do any[thing] for you creator wouldn’t [you] —
